newsitem.title: USA: New York mayor denies report of affair.
newsitem.headline: New York mayor denies report of affair.

text.p: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani on Monday vehemently denied the story few had read but much of New York was talking about -- that he was having an affair with a 32-year-old aide and his marriage was ruined.
From his morning appearance at the opening bell of the New York Stock Exchange to his regular news briefing at City Hall, Giuliani called the report in Vanity Fair magazine "untrue" and "malicious."

The report comes just three months before the city's mayoral election in which Giuliani is the heavy favourite for re-election. He has gained wide support as the crime rate has fallen and the city is perceived to be more livable.

Vanity Fair reported in its September issue, which does not reach New York's newsstands until Wednesday, that the 53-year-old mayor was allegedly carrying on an extramarital affair with communications director Cristyne Lategano that started during out-of-state campaign trips in 1994.

The article, which quoted unidentified sources and unidentified former aides, predicted that Giuliani and his actress-reporter wife Donna Hanover, 46, would separate after the November mayoral election.

"I really think the more I talk about it, the more I just dignify the article," Giuliani told reporters. "I think the best thing for me to say about the article is it's untrue, it's false, it's based on unnamed sources."
Hanover issued a brief statement that did not address the article, but referred to her charitable activities as the mayor's wife and her family.
"We are a family and we will remain a family," Hanover told reporters outside her office on Monday. Giuliani and Hanover have two children, Andrew, 11, and Caroline, 7.
Lategano, who rose swiftly through the ranks of the Giuliani administration from a young campaign aide to leading adviser, also said the reported affair was not true.
"When a woman works closely with her male boss, it's called intimate. When a man does the same, it's called loyal," said Lategano, known at City Hall as a workaholic.
Gossip columnists have hinted at a possible affair before but Vanity Fair was the first publication to actually come out and report it as true.
